metadata.case_name: Seth Sobhagmal Lodha v. Edward Mills Co. Ltd. & Ors.

facts.text: Edward-Mills Co. Ltd. is a joint stock company situate in Beawar, Ajmer-Merwara.
Seth Gadh Mal Lodha and Rai Sahib Moti Lal (respondent No. 2) were chairman and managing director respectively since 1916 per articles of the company.
Seth Gadh Mal Lodha represented his family firm of Kanwal Nain Hamir Singh; Rai Sahib Moti Lal represented joint family firm of Champa Lal Ram Swaroop.
On 1st July, 1938, Rai Sahib Moti Lal and his firm adjudged insolvents by Bombay High Court, vacating office of managing director; members of his firm ineligible.
By board resolution on 18th July, 1938, Gadh Mal Lodha appointed managing director in place of Rai Sahib Moti Lal.
Gadh Mal Lodha died on 11th January, 1942.
Board of directors appointed Seth Sobhagmal Lodha to act as chairman and managing director till appointment by company.
Extraordinary general meeting called for 8th February, 1942, for election of chairman; conflict between groups of Sobhagmal Lodha and Moti Lal.
Chairman dissolved meeting; supporters of Moti Lal continued and passed resolution appointing him sole agent and chairman for 20 years at 10% of profits.

Seth Sobhagmal approached District Judge, Ajmer, for general meeting under court supervision; allowed on 11th February, 1942, meeting fixed for 12th February, 1942, under Seth Sobhagmal's chairmanship.
Respondent No. 2 filed revision in Judicial Commissioner impugning order; revision allowed, directed resolution of 8th February, 1942, be acted upon.

Appellant filed Civil Suit No. 28 of 1942 for quashing resolution of 8th February, 1942; prayed declaration that appointment of defendant No. 2 illegal, invalid, ultra vires, no right to act as chairman/managing director; and receiver appointment.
Plaint bore court-fee of Rs. 10; objection raised, appellant paid ad valorem Rs. 51,000 for relief No. 2.

Additional District Judge, Ajmer (Judge, Small Causes and Additional District Judge) dismissed suit on 13th March, 1944, as not maintainable relating to internal management without impleading directors.
Appeal to Judicial Commissioner, Ajmer-Merwara in Civil First Appeal No. 16 of 1944; memorandum stamped Rs. 10, stated relief No. 2 given up.
Objection to court-fee on memorandum; Judicial Commissioner ordered proper fees in a month, no reasons given.
Fee not paid; appeal dismissed with costs on 22nd March, 1945.
Application for leave to Privy Council refused; in order, explained reasons for fee demand referencing s.42 Specific Relief Act, consequential relief.
Special leave granted by Privy Council limited to court-fee question.

legal_issues.text: Whether the memorandum of appeal presented to the High Court court-fee was payable under section 7(iv)(e) or article 17 of Schedule II of the Court-Fees Act.
Whether the order of the Judicial Commissioner demanding additional court-fee can be sustained in law.
Scope of section 12 of the Court-Fees Act: whether final as to category of suit/appeal or only valuation simpliciter.

petitioner_arguments.text: Memorandum of appeal properly stamped under article 17 Schedule II as only declaratory relief claimed; relinquished second relief (receiver).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Article 17 Schedule II Court-Fees Act; precedents like Brahmnandam v. Secretary of State, Ram Prasad v. Bhiman

petitioner_arguments.text: Judicial Commissioner could not canvass merits (s.42 Specific Relief Act) to determine stamping; that relates to merits, not proper institution.

respondent_arguments.text: First relief includes consequential relief (no right to act as chairman/managing director), not purely declaratory; additional fee required.
Section 12 Court-Fees Act makes decision final, including category and valuation.

court_reasoning.text: Relief in memorandum purely declaratory; appellant can relinquish part of claim unless inseparable; properly stamped under art.17 Sch.II.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Memorandum determines value for court-fee; open to restrict claim.

court_reasoning.text: Judicial Commissioner erred in demanding fee based on eliminated prayer; went into merits (maintainability without receiver), no jurisdiction for that on fee question.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Fee determined by appeal subject-matter as presented.

court_reasoning.text: Section 12 finality limited to valuation/appraisement simpliciter, not category (question of law); reconciles with CPC O.VII r.11 appealability.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Category antecedent to valuation; consensus of judicial opinion supports restricted view.

court_reasoning.text: Even if s.12 comprehensive, Judicial Commissioner decided maintainability, not fee question per s.12.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No finality attaches to merits decision disguised as fee order.

holdings.text: Memorandum of appeal properly stamped under article 17 Schedule II as purely declaratory.
Judicial Commissioner's order demanding additional fee erroneous; no jurisdiction to go into merits for fee purpose.
Section 12 Court-Fees Act finality limited to valuation simpliciter, not category or merits.

precedents_cited.case_name: Brahmnandam v. Secretary of State for India
precedents_cited.relevance: Appellant can relinquish part of claim for court-fee purposes.
Appellant can give up portion of claim.

precedents_cited.case_name: Karam Chand v. Jullundur Bank Ltd.
Chuni Lal v. Sheo Charan Lalman
In re Omrao Mirza v. Mary Jones
precedents_cited.relevance: Finality of s.12 taken away by CPC.

precedents_cited.case_name: Tara Prasanna Chongdar v. Nrisingha Moorari Pal
Tariman Khatun v. Secretary of State for India in Council
precedents_cited.relevance: Finality limited to valuation pure and simple, not category.

precedents_cited.case_name: Madana Mohana Naiko v. Krupasindhu Naiko
Krishnaji Bari Dhandhere v. Gopal Narain Dhandhere
Chandramoni Koer v. Basdeo Narain Singh

statutes_cited.name: Court-Fees Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Determines stamping of memorandum based on relief claimed; s.12 finality limited to valuation simpliciter.

statutes_cited.name: Specific Relief Act
statutes_cited.relevance: No declaration if plaintiff omits consequential relief; but not for court-fee category.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Rejection of plaint appealable as decree; reconciles with Court-Fees Act.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; held memorandum of appeal properly stamped with Rs.10 under art.17 Sch.II Court-Fees Act as purely declaratory after relinquishing receiver relief; Judicial Commissioner's order erroneous, exceeding jurisdiction by deciding merits; s.12 finality not applicable to category or merits.
outcome.relief_granted: Order of Judicial Commissioner set aside; memorandum held properly stamped.

key_quotes.text: The relief claimed in the memorandum of appeal determines the value of the appeal for purposes of court-fee.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: It is always open to the appellant in appeal to give up a portion of his claim and to restrict it.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Affirms appellant's right to relinquish reliefs.

key_quotes.text: The finality declared by section 12 is limited only to the question of valuation pure and simple and does not relate to the category under which a certain suit falls.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key interpretation of s.12 Court-Fees Act.
